title: Cate Blanchett and Jorja Smith are icons at Women of the Year awards
text:
The Queens have arrived (Picture: Richard Young/REX )

It’s that time of the year again, where amazing women come together to rule the red carpet for Harper Bazaar’s Women of the Year Awards.

This year, we had the likes of Helena Bonham Carter, Cate Blanchett, Jorja Smith, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and Letitia Wright grace the winners’ stage.

Many of the inspirational women this year are British which has been the push we all deserved.

Helena – who joined the critically acclaimed series The Crown as Princess Margaret – won this year’s British Icon award.

The eccentric actress attended the London event with her partner Rye Dag Holmboe wearing a signature Helena outfit that consisted of a giant black ribbon in her hair and a super flared dress.

It’s not an event unless the actress turns up in a jaw-dropping ensemble and beautifully crazy hair.

During her exclusive interview with Harper’s Bazaar, Helena said: ‘My interests are more diverse than pretending to be other people. We’re really lucky as women to be living now, because we’re allowed to do anything.’

The luckiest man on earth? (Picture: David M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty Images for Harper’s Bazaar)

Jorja appeared on Drake’s Get It Together (Picture: Ricky Vigil M/GC Images)

Like becoming an icon, mayhaps?

Meanwhile, Jorja Smith, 22, brightened up the star-studded even in a stunning mustard yellow dress and collected her award for Musician of the Year.

The Be Honest singer took the world by storm with her first single Blue Lights after Drake had her on one of his albums.

Jorja has already achieved a lot more than many do at the same age, and we couldn’t think of anyone else to receive the award.

She became the first unsigned artist to receive the Critics’ Choice prize at the Brit Awards and her debut album earning endless Grammy and Mercury nominations.

Cate has received endless awards (Picture: Beretta/Sims/REX)

Rosie won Editor’s Choice (Picture: David M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty Images for Harper’s Bazaar)

‘I don’t really have goals or dreams because I don’t like being disappointed,’ Jorja had said to Harper’s Bazaar. ‘But I’m definitely living a dream.’

The Woman of the Year awards honour ‘extraordinary and inspirational’ women so we’re not surprised Jorja, Helena, Letitia Wright (Breakthrough Talent) and Cate Blanchett earned awards.

Cate – who starred in Ocean’s 8 – won the Philanthropy Award on the night for the outstanding work she has done throughout her life.

The actress has always been outspoken about the MeToo and Time’s Up campaigns, and as president of the jury at the Cannes Film Festival last year, led a protest of 82 women in the industry representing the total number of female director who work has been screened in competition there (compared with more than 1,600 men).
